page.title: International reactions to the 2011 Egyptian revolution

rev.diff:
Line 22: Line 22:
}}</ref> On 6 February, protesters in Cairo's Tahrir Square accused Iran of interfering in Egyptian affairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/311143 |title=Thousands flock to Tahrir to honor protests' martyrs | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>
}}</ref> On 6 February, protesters in Cairo's Tahrir Square accused Iran of interfering in Egyptian affairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/311143 |title=Thousands flock to Tahrir to honor protests' martyrs | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>
*: [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Iranian Foreign Minister]] [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] hoped that the Egyptians' "high aims, national demands and resurrection of their glory could be achieved in the very near future." [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Iranian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] spokesman [[Ramin Mehmanparast]] called on Egypt to "abide by the rightful demands of the nation."<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Egypt Protests Draw Mixed Reaction in Region|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/29/egypt.middle.east.reaction/|work=[[CNN]]|date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> There were "solidarity" protests outside the Egyptian interests section.{{clarify|date=January 2011}}<!--which embassy?-->
*: [[Foreign Affairs Minister of Iran|Iranian Foreign Minister]] [[Ali Akbar Salehi]] hoped that the Egyptians' "high aims, national demands and resurrection of their glory could be achieved in the very near future." [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Iran)|Iranian Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] spokesman [[Ramin Mehmanparast]] called on Egypt to "abide by the rightful demands of the nation."<ref>{{cite news |author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Egypt Protests Draw Mixed Reaction in Region|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/29/egypt.middle.east.reaction/|work=[[CNN]]|date=29 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> There were "solidarity" protests outside the Egyptian interests section.{{clarify|date=January 2011}}<!--which embassy?-->
â
*: [[Islamic Consultative Assembly (Iran)|Iranian parliament speaker]] [[Ali Larijani]] said, "The voice of the brave people of Egypt is the voice of revolution. The start of this revolution has astonished the despotic regimes of the region. The parliament supports the uprising of the Tunisian and Egyptian people." He described the protests as "the revolution of the noble."<ref>{{cite web|author=Name * |url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/01/iran-backs-egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/ |title=Iran backs Egypt's 'revolution of the noble' | Pakistan Today | Latest news, Breaking news, Pakistan News, World news, business, sport and multimedia |publisher=Pakistan Today |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Iran backed the protests. Parliament speaker [[Ali Larijani]] called the uprising the "revolution of the noble". He compared Western reaction to the protests with their reaction to the 1979 [[Islamic Revolution]].<ref>{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|title=Iran Backs Egypt's 'Revolution of the Noble'|publisher=''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[The Times of India]]'')|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/middle-east/Iran-backs-Egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/articleshow/7392036.cms|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=31 January 2011}}{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref>
+
*: [[Islamic Consultative Assembly (Iran)|Iranian parliament speaker]] [[Ali Larijani]] said, "The voice of the brave people of Egypt is the voice of revolution. The start of this revolution has astonished the despotic regimes of the region. The parliament supports the uprising of the Tunisian and Egyptian people." He described the protests as "the revolution of the noble."<ref>{{cite web|author=Name * |url=http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/01/iran-backs-egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/ |title=Iran backs Egypt's 'revolution of the noble' | Pakistan Today | Latest news, Breaking news, Pakistan News, World news, business, sport and multimedia |publisher=Pakistan Today |date=2011-01-30 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Iran backed the protests. Parliament speaker [[Ali Larijani]] called the uprising the "revolution of the noble". He compared Western reaction to the protests with their reaction to the 1979 [[Islamic Revolution]].<ref>http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2011/01/iran-backs-egypts-revolution-of-the-noble/</ref>
** [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]], former presidential candidates and the leaders of the [[Iranian Green Movement|Green Movement]], released a statement from their virtual [[house arrest]] in Tehran, assuring the Egyptians, "No power can suppress the people's will and demand. Sooner or later, autocratic and tyrant power[s] are sentenced to vanish."<ref name="Khamenei"/>
** [[Mir Hossein Mousavi]] and [[Mehdi Karroubi]], former presidential candidates and the leaders of the [[Iranian Green Movement|Green Movement]], released a statement from their virtual [[house arrest]] in Tehran, assuring the Egyptians, "No power can suppress the people's will and demand. Sooner or later, autocratic and tyrant power[s] are sentenced to vanish."<ref name="Khamenei"/>
* {{flag|Iraq}} â Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] stated, "The people have the right to express what they want without being persecuted... One of the characteristics of a lack of democracy is when a leader rules for 30 or 40 years. It is a difficult issue for people, it is intolerable and change is necessary."<ref>{{cite news
* {{flag|Iraq}} â Prime Minister [[Nouri al-Maliki]] stated, "The people have the right to express what they want without being persecuted... Line 71: Line 71:
}}</ref> The arrest of two Brazilian journalists in Cairo on 2 February prompted the Ministry of External Relations to raise its tone in remarks about the political crisis in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/internacional,apos-prisao-de-jornalistas-no-egito-itamaraty-eleva-tom,674951,0.htm |title=ApÃ³s prisÃ£o de jornalistas no Egito, Itamaraty eleva tom ("After the Arrest of Journalists in Egypt, Foreign Ministry Raises Tone") (in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]) |publisher=Estadao.com.br |date= |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> it "deplore[d] the violent clashes [and] denounce[d] the arrests of Brazilian journalists Corban Costa, from [[RÃ¡dio Nacional]], and Gilvan Rocha, from [[TV Brasil]], and expects that Egyptian authorities take the appropriate measures to uphold the civil liberties and to protect the population at large and the foreigners on the ground from bodily harm."<ref>[[Press release]] (3 February 2011). [http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/situacao-no-egito-1 "Situation in Egypt"]. [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Brazilian Ministry of External Relations]]. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>
}}</ref> The arrest of two Brazilian journalists in Cairo on 2 February prompted the Ministry of External Relations to raise its tone in remarks about the political crisis in Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.estadao.com.br/noticias/internacional,apos-prisao-de-jornalistas-no-egito-itamaraty-eleva-tom,674951,0.htm |title=ApÃ³s prisÃ£o de jornalistas no Egito, Itamaraty eleva tom ("After the Arrest of Journalists in Egypt, Foreign Ministry Raises Tone") (in [[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]) |publisher=Estadao.com.br |date= |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> it "deplore[d] the violent clashes [and] denounce[d] the arrests of Brazilian journalists Corban Costa, from [[RÃ¡dio Nacional]], and Gilvan Rocha, from [[TV Brasil]], and expects that Egyptian authorities take the appropriate measures to uphold the civil liberties and to protect the population at large and the foreigners on the ground from bodily harm."<ref>[[Press release]] (3 February 2011). [http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/situacao-no-egito-1 "Situation in Egypt"]. [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Brazilian Ministry of External Relations]]. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref>

â
{{quote box|width=216px|quote="Violence will not address the grievances of the Egyptian people, and suppressing ideas never succeeds in making them go away.... Around the world governments have an obligation to respond to their citizens.... All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion. That is the single standard by which the people of Egypt will achieve the future they deserve."|source=â Barack Obama<ref>{{cite web|author=Werner, Erica|url=http://wokv.com/common/ap/2011/01/29/D9L1UHTG0.html |title=Obama Admonishes Egypt's Mubarak on Protests |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[WOKV]]'') |date=undated (copyright 2011) |accessdate=2 February 2011}}{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hJYBPPuG4Y1vq7XMe3NnsL7yOqRQ?docId=e5469a82800b40e498667d555837548f |title=Obama Calls for Restraint, Reform in Egypt |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[Google News]]'') |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}{{dead link|date=April 2011}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://www.presidency.ucsb.edu/ws/index.php?pid=88942&st=&st1=|title=Remarks on the Situation in Egypt|publisher=John T. Woolley and Gerhard Peters, The American Presidency Project [online]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 29 January 2011}}</ref>}}
+
{{quote box|width=216px|quote="Violence will not address the grievances of the Egyptian people, and suppressing ideas never succeeds in making them go away.... Woolley and Gerhard Peters, The American Presidency Project [online]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 29 January 2011}}</ref>}}
* {{flag|Canada}} â [[Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Lawrence Cannon]] said that Egypt remains an [[Canada-Egypt relations|important partner]] for Canada and urged "the Egyptian government to ensure full freedom of political expression for its citizens." He said the Canadian government "continues to stand by the people of Egypt as they demand democratic reforms and respect for human rights. We urge the Government of Egypt to begin an immediate transition toward serious democratic reform."<ref>(2 February 2011). [http://www.international.gc.ca/media/aff/news-communiques/2011/044.aspx?lang=eng "Minister Cannon Condemns Violence in Egypt"]. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Canada}} â [[Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister]] [[Lawrence Cannon]] said that Egypt remains an [[Canada-Egypt relations|important partner]] for Canada and urged "the Egyptian government to ensure full freedom of political expression for its citizens." He said the Canadian government "continues to stand by the people of Egypt as they demand democratic reforms and respect for human rights. We urge the Government of Egypt to begin an immediate transition toward serious democratic reform."<ref>(2 February 2011). [http://www.international.gc.ca/media/aff/news-communiques/2011/044.aspx?lang=eng "Minister Cannon Condemns Violence in Egypt"]. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Chile}} â A press release from the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Chile)|Chilean Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] declared that it is "permanently following the evolution of the events".<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in spanish. at minimum, needs english translation of spanish headline appended in "trans_title" field}} {{cite news|title=Egipto: comunicado de prensa de CancillerÃ­a|url=http://www.minrel.gov.cl/prontus_minrel/site/artic/20110131/pags/20110131091403.php|trans_title=|language=[[Spanish language|Spanish]]|work=[[MINREL]]|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=31 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Chile}} â A press release from the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Chile)|Chilean Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] declared that it is "permanently following the evolution of the events".<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in spanish. at minimum, needs english translation of spanish headline appended in "trans_title" field}} {{cite news|title=Egipto: comunicado de prensa de CancillerÃ­a|url=http://www.minrel.gov.cl/prontus_minrel/site/artic/20110131/pags/20110131091403.php|trans_title=|language=[[Spanish language|Spanish]]|work=[[MINREL]]|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=31 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Colombia}} â [[President of Colombia|Colombian President]] [[Juan Manuel Santos]] asked Mubarak to ensure the situation returns to normal. He said that "[the Colombian people] moves along with the Egyptian people in search of their welfare, freedom and plain use of their human rights and trusts that Mubarak and his government would promote in a short term the return to calm and the strengthening of the democratic institutions." He told their embassy to be prepared to assist Colombian citizens in Egypt.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in spanish. at minimum, needs english translation of spanish headline appended next to spanish headline}} [[Staff writer]] (31 January 2011). [http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/santos-pide-a-presidente-egipcio-fortalecer-instituciones-democraticas_8809619-4 "Santos pide a presidente egipcio fortalecer instituciones democrÃ¡ticas"] (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]). ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]''). Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Colombia}} â [[President of Colombia|Colombian President]] [[Juan Manuel Santos]] asked Mubarak to ensure the situation returns to normal. He said that "[the Colombian people] moves along with the Egyptian people in search of their welfare, freedom and plain use of their human rights and trusts that Mubarak and his government would promote in a short term the return to calm and the strengthening of the democratic institutions." He told their embassy to be prepared to assist Colombian citizens in Egypt.<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=headline in spanish. at minimum, needs english translation of spanish headline appended next to spanish headline}} [[Staff writer]] (31 January 2011). [http://www.eltiempo.com/politica/santos-pide-a-presidente-egipcio-fortalecer-instituciones-democraticas_8809619-4 "Santos pide a presidente egipcio fortalecer instituciones democrÃ¡ticas"] (in [[Spanish language|Spanish]]). ''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]''). Retrieved 1 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Cuba}} â [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Bruno RodrÃ­guez Parrilla]] hoped for a positive outcome to the protests as one that "meets the interests of the Egyptian people and nation (''[[sic]]'')."<ref>(3 February 2011). [http://www.cubaminrex.cu/english/Actualidad/2011/enero/Cuba%20rejects.html Cuba Rejects U.S. Meddling in Egypt"]. Foreign Affairs of Cuba. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
* {{flag|Cuba}} â [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]] [[Bruno RodrÃ­guez Parrilla]] hoped for a positive outcome to the protests as one that "meets the interests of the Egyptian people and nation (''[[sic]]'')."<ref>(3 February 2011). [http://www.cubaminrex.cu/english/Actualidad/2011/enero/Cuba%20rejects.html Cuba Rejects U.S. Meddling in Egypt"]. Foreign Affairs of Cuba. Retrieved 5 February 2011.</ref>
â
* {{flag|United States}} â [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]], noting that he had spoken with the Egyptian president, stated that his first concern is preventing injury or loss of life. He remarked, "What's needed right now are concrete steps that advance the rights of the Egyptian people...Ultimately the future of Egypt will be determined by the Egyptian people. The United States will always be a committed partner to that future, with the Egyptian government, and with the Egyptian people." He recalled that in his [[A New Beginning|speech in Cairo]] in June 2009 he had stated, "All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion," and called upon the Egyptian government to restore its people's access to the internet. He called on all parties to refrain from violence in their efforts to bring about a solution.<ref name="Barack Obama">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/28/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests Live Updates|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011|location=London|first1=Matthew|last1=Weaver|first2=Haroon|last2=Siddique|first3=Richard|last3=Adams|first4=Tim|last4=Hill}}</ref> He said that the Egyptian protesters have "universal" rights, including the right to peaceful assembly and association, free speech, and âthe ability to determine their own destiny. [...] These are human rights and the United States will stand up for them everywhere."<ref>Johnston, Nicholas; Brower, Kate Andersen (29 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/28 January 2011/obama-says-mubarak-must-take-concrete-steps-to-deliver-pledge-on-reforms.html "Obama Tells Mubarak He Must Stick to Pledge of Democratic Reforms in Egypt"]{{dead link|date=April 2011}}. ''[[Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 29 January 2011.</ref> White House spokesman [[Robert Gibbs]] expressed anger at the pace of change in Egypt, saying the transition should happen quickly, which he also said would determine US aid to the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/politics/2011/02/us-angered-over-egypt-hopeful-over-yemen-jordan |title=US angered over Egypt, hopeful over Yemen, Jordan | The Associated Press | Politics |publisher=Washington Examiner |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Gibbs posted a statement on [[Twitter]] expressing concern "about violence in Egypt", adding the "government must respect the rights of the Egyptian people & turn on social networking and the internet".<ref name="Twitter">{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/PressSec/status/31026478648926208|title=Gibbs on Twitter|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref>
+
* {{flag|United States}} â [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Barack Obama]], noting that he had spoken with the Egyptian president, stated that his first concern is preventing injury or loss of life. He remarked, "What's needed right now are concrete steps that advance the rights of the Egyptian people...Ultimately the future of Egypt will be determined by the Egyptian people. The United States will always be a committed partner to that future, with the Egyptian government, and with the Egyptian people." He recalled that in his [[A New Beginning|speech in Cairo]] in June 2009 he had stated, "All governments must maintain power through consent, not coercion," and called upon the Egyptian government to restore its people's access to the internet. He called on all parties to refrain from violence in their efforts to bring about a solution.<ref name="Barack Obama">{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/28/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests Live Updates|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011|location=London|first1=Matthew|last1=Weaver|first2=Haroon|last2=Siddique|first3=Richard|last3=Adams|first4=Tim|last4=Hill}}</ref> He said that the Egyptian protesters have "universal" rights, including the right to peaceful assembly and association, free speech, and âthe ability to determine their own destiny. [...] These are human rights and the United States will stand up for them everywhere."<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/obama-says-mubarak-must-take-concrete-steps-to-deliver-pledge-on-reforms.html</ref> White House spokesman [[Robert Gibbs]] expressed anger at the pace of change in Egypt, saying the transition should happen quickly, which he also said would determine US aid to the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://washingtonexaminer.com/politics/2011/02/us-angered-over-egypt-hopeful-over-yemen-jordan |title=US angered over Egypt, hopeful over Yemen, Jordan | The Associated Press | Politics |publisher=Washington Examiner |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-04-27}}</ref> Gibbs posted a statement on [[Twitter]] expressing concern "about violence in Egypt", adding the "government must respect the rights of the Egyptian people & turn on social networking and the internet".<ref name="Twitter">{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/PressSec/status/31026478648926208|title=Gibbs on Twitter|date=28 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref>
*: [[Vice President of the United States|US Vice President]] [[Joseph Biden]] said Hosni Mubarak "has been an ally of ours in a number of things. And heâs been very responsible on, relative to geopolitical interest in the region, the Middle East peace efforts: the actions Egypt has taken relative to normalising relationship with Israel."<ref name="Joe Biden">{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Dan|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/01/exclusive-biden-discusses-unrest-in-egypt-keeping-us-competitive.html|title=Exclusive: Biden Discusses Unrest in Egypt, Keeping U.S. Competitive|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref>
*: [[Vice President of the United States|US Vice President]] [[Joseph Biden]] said Hosni Mubarak "has been an ally of ours in a number of things. And heâs been very responsible on, relative to geopolitical interest in the region, the Middle East peace efforts: the actions Egypt has taken relative to normalising relationship with Israel."<ref name="Joe Biden">{{cite news|last=Murphy|first=Dan|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/01/exclusive-biden-discusses-unrest-in-egypt-keeping-us-competitive.html|title=Exclusive: Biden Discusses Unrest in Egypt, Keeping U.S. Competitive|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate= 28 January 2011}}</ref>
*: [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said, "The Egyptian government has an important opportunity to be responsive to the aspirations of the Egyptian people, and pursue political, economic and social reforms that can improve their lives and help Egypt prosper."<ref name="Clinton">{{cite web|author=Awad, Marwa; Dziadoszurl, Alexander|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wrni/news.newsmain/article/0/0/1754229/.World./Egypt's.Mubarak.faces.unprecedented.protests|title=Egypt's Mubarak Faces Unprecedented Protests|publisher=''[[Reuters]]'' (via ''[[WRNI]]'')|date=25 January 2011|accessdate= 31 January 2011}}</ref> She told ''Al Jazeera'' that Mubarak has been an ally of the US in the past because he has maintained the [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] with Israel in maintaining stability.<!--from tv-->{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} She said the US supports an "orderly transition."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130164532649572.html |title=''Al Jazeera'' Undeterred by Egypt Curb â Will Continue Its Comprehensive Coverage of Landmark Events There, Says Network Chief|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> On 8 March Clinton said Egypt's transition to democracy would be incomplete if women were not equal partners with men in creating the new society. She criticised the lack of women involved in efforts to draft a new constitution, saying in part, "The women in Egypt and [[Tunisia]] and other nations have just as much right as the men to remake their governments â to make them responsive, accountable, transparent."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/08/clinton-women-middle-east-international-womens-day_n_832974.html|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=9 March 2011|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Clinton: Women Must Get Role In Middle East Transition}}</ref>
*: [[United States Secretary of State|US Secretary of State]] [[Hillary Clinton]] said, "The Egyptian government has an important opportunity to be responsive to the aspirations of the Egyptian people, and pursue political, economic and social reforms that can improve their lives and help Egypt prosper."<ref name="Clinton">{{cite web|author=Awad, Marwa; Dziadoszurl, Alexander|url=http://www.publicbroadcasting.net/wrni/news.newsmain/article/0/0/1754229/.World./Egypt's.Mubarak.faces.unprecedented.protests|title=Egypt's Mubarak Faces Unprecedented Protests|publisher=''[[Reuters]]'' (via ''[[WRNI]]'')|date=25 January 2011|accessdate= 31 January 2011}}</ref> She told ''Al Jazeera'' that Mubarak has been an ally of the US in the past because he has maintained the [[EgyptâIsrael Peace Treaty|peace treaty]] with Israel in maintaining stability.<!--from tv-->{{Citation needed|date=January 2011}} She said the US supports an "orderly transition."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130164532649572.html |title=''Al Jazeera'' Undeterred by Egypt Curb â Will Continue Its Comprehensive Coverage of Landmark Events There, Says Network Chief|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> On 8 March Clinton said Egypt's transition to democracy would be incomplete if women were not equal partners with men in creating the new society. She criticised the lack of women involved in efforts to draft a new constitution, saying in part, "The women in Egypt and [[Tunisia]] and other nations have just as much right as the men to remake their governments â to make them responsive, accountable, transparent."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/03/08/clinton-women-middle-east-international-womens-day_n_832974.html|date=8 March 2011|accessdate=9 March 2011|agency=The Huffington Post|title=Clinton: Women Must Get Role In Middle East Transition}}</ref>
Line 101: Line 101:
<!--3 February 2011- contrary to norm, put temporary spacers between countries for easier editing; can be removed after article is more finessed-->
<!--3 February 2011- contrary to norm, put temporary spacers between countries for easier editing; can be removed after article is more finessed-->
* {{flag|Austria}} â On 3 February [[Foreign Minister of Austria|Austrian Foreign Minister]] [[Michael Spindelegger]] condemned the violence. "It is more necessary than ever for talks to be started without delay between the opposition and the government in order to prevent the situation from getting further out of control. This also entails calling those responsible for acts of violence to account, and swiftly."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|url=http://www.bmeia.gv.at/en/foreign-ministry/news/presseaussendungen/2011/spindelegger-zu-aegypten-demonstrationen-koennen-nicht-durch-gewalt-mundtot-gemacht-werden.html|title=Spindelegger on Egypt: 'Demonstrations Cannot be Silenced by Violence' â Foreign Minister Very Concerned About Developments in Egypt and Calls for Renunciation of Force|publisher=[[Foreign Ministry of Austria|Austrian Foreign Ministry]]|date= 3 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Austria}} â On 3 February [[Foreign Minister of Austria|Austrian Foreign Minister]] [[Michael Spindelegger]] condemned the violence. "It is more necessary than ever for talks to be started without delay between the opposition and the government in order to prevent the situation from getting further out of control. This also entails calling those responsible for acts of violence to account, and swiftly."<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|url=http://www.bmeia.gv.at/en/foreign-ministry/news/presseaussendungen/2011/spindelegger-zu-aegypten-demonstrationen-koennen-nicht-durch-gewalt-mundtot-gemacht-werden.html|title=Spindelegger on Egypt: 'Demonstrations Cannot be Silenced by Violence' â Foreign Minister Very Concerned About Developments in Egypt and Calls for Renunciation of Force|publisher=[[Foreign Ministry of Austria|Austrian Foreign Ministry]]|date= 3 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>

* {{flag|Belarus}} â [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Belarus)|Belarussian Foreign Ministry]] Press Secretary Andrei Savinykh declared:{{when|date=February 2011}} "We are convinced that street clashes and violence is a bad way to solve pressing social and community issues. * {{flag|Belarus}} â [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Belarus)|Belarussian Foreign Ministry]] Press Secretary Andrei Savinykh declared:{{when|date=February 2011}} "We are convinced that street clashes and violence is a bad way to solve pressing social and community issues. * {{flag|Belgium}} â In a statement released on 27 January, Belgian Deputy Prime Minister, Foreign Minister [[Steven Vanackere]] and Minister of Civil Service, Public Enterprises and Institutional Reforms deplored the deaths. He hopes that the protest will strengthen the process of democratisation and socio-economic reform in Egypt. He pointed out the importance of freedom of speech and media.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|url=http://diplomatie.belgium.be/en/newsroom/news/press_releases/foreign_affairs/2011/01/ni_270111_vanackere_betogingen_egypte.jsp |title=Steven Vanackere on the Situation in Egypt |publisher=[[FPS Foreign Affairs Belgium|FPS Foreign Affairs, Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation]] |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Belgium}} â In a statement released on 27 January, Belgian Deputy Prime Minister, Foreign Minister [[Steven Vanackere]] and Minister of Civil Service, Public Enterprises and Institutional Reforms deplored the deaths. He hopes that the protest will strengthen the process of democratisation and socio-economic reform in Egypt. He pointed out the importance of freedom of speech and media.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|url=http://diplomatie.belgium.be/en/newsroom/news/press_releases/foreign_affairs/2011/01/ni_270111_vanackere_betogingen_egypte.jsp |title=Steven Vanackere on the Situation in Egypt |publisher=[[FPS Foreign Affairs Belgium|FPS Foreign Affairs, Foreign Trade and Development Cooperation]] |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Bulgaria}} â The Foreign Ministry condemned the violent response to the protests, and expressed condolences for the deaths.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.bg/en/news/view/30752|title=The events of last week demonstrate the need for serious social and economic reforms that can guarantee democracy and human rights in Egypt.|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Bulgaria|date= 30 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Bulgaria}} â The Foreign Ministry condemned the violent response to the protests, and expressed condolences for the deaths.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.bg/en/news/view/30752|title=The events of last week demonstrate the need for serious social and economic reforms that can guarantee democracy and human rights in Egypt.|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Bulgaria|date= 30 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
Line 115: Line 115:
* {{flag|Germany}} â Foreign Minister [[Guido Westerwelle]] said he was "very concerned" and called on all involved to show restraint.<ref>{{cite web|author=Al-Shalchi, Adeel|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/211587/egypt-protesters-clash-for-2nd-day-with-police |title=Egypt Protesters Clash for 2nd Day with Police |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[GMA News and Public Affairs]]'')|date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Later [[Angela Merkel]] called upon all involved, and especially the Egyptian government and the president, to allow peaceful demonstrations, to give freedom of opinion a chance. "We have to come to a peaceful dialogue in Egypt because the stability of the country is of extraordinary importance."<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12316019 |title=In Quotes: Reaction to Egypt Protests |work=[[BBC News]] |date= 30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Germany}} â Foreign Minister [[Guido Westerwelle]] said he was "very concerned" and called on all involved to show restraint.<ref>{{cite web|author=Al-Shalchi, Adeel|url=http://www.gmanews.tv/story/211587/egypt-protesters-clash-for-2nd-day-with-police |title=Egypt Protesters Clash for 2nd Day with Police |publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[GMA News and Public Affairs]]'')|date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Later [[Angela Merkel]] called upon all involved, and especially the Egyptian government and the president, to allow peaceful demonstrations, to give freedom of opinion a chance. "We have to come to a peaceful dialogue in Egypt because the stability of the country is of extraordinary importance."<ref name="bbc.co.uk">{{cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12316019 |title=In Quotes: Reaction to Egypt Protests |work=[[BBC News]] |date= 30 January 2011 |accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Greece}} â The Foreign Ministry said in a statement on 30 January that it plans to evacuate its citizens from Egypt.<ref name="Greece evacuate Egypt">{{cite news |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/foreign-countries-evacuate-citizens-as-cairo-unrest-grows-377303.html |title=Foreign Countries Evacuate Citizens as Cairo Unrest Grows |last=Bladd |first=Joanne |work=[[Arabian Business]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
* {{flag|Greece}} â The Foreign Ministry said in a statement on 30 January that it plans to evacuate its citizens from Egypt.<ref name="Greece evacuate Egypt">{{cite news |url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/foreign-countries-evacuate-citizens-as-cairo-unrest-grows-377303.html |title=Foreign Countries Evacuate Citizens as Cairo Unrest Grows |last=Bladd |first=Joanne |work=[[Arabian Business]] |date=30 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
â
* {{flag|Italy}} â Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]] said that he hoped for "continuity in the government" as Western leaders wanted a "more democratic system without ruptures with a president like Mubarak that all the Western hemisphere, including the U.S., had considered the wisest man and a reference point in all of the Middle East." He played down the scale of the protests by saying that there were "really few" demonstrators out of a population of 80 million.<ref>Krause-Jackson, Flavia (4 February 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/4 February 2011/berlusconi-says-west-considered-mubarak-wisest-man-in-mideast.html "Berlusconi Says West Considered Mubarak 'Wisest Man' in Mideast"]{{dead link|date=April 2011}}. ''[[Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 6 February 2011.</ref>
+
* {{flag|Italy}} â Prime Minister [[Silvio Berlusconi]] said that he hoped for "continuity in the government" as Western leaders wanted a "more democratic system without ruptures with a president like Mubarak that all the Western hemisphere, including the U.S., had considered the wisest man and a reference point in all of the Middle East." He played down the scale of the protests by saying that there were "really few" demonstrators out of a population of 80 million.<ref>http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-04/berlusconi-says-west-considered-mubarak-wisest-man-in-mideast.html</ref>
*: The Foreign Ministry gave a statement where they expressed deep regret over the civilian casualties. They urged the immediate cessation of every kind of violence, and called for respect for civil rights and for freedom of speech and communication, including the right to hold peaceful rallies. They pointed out that Egypt's stability is a priority for their country.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/>
*: The Foreign Ministry gave a statement where they expressed deep regret over the civilian casualties. They urged the immediate cessation of every kind of violence, and called for respect for civil rights and for freedom of speech and communication, including the right to hold peaceful rallies. They pointed out that Egypt's stability is a priority for their country.<ref name="bbc.co.uk"/>
* {{flag|Latvia}} â The Foreign Ministry of Affairs was concerned about the situation in Egypt, and advised their citizens not to travel to Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.gov.lv/en/news/press-releases/2011/january/28-2/ |title=Comment by Foreign Ministry Press Secretary on situation in Egypt |publisher=Mfa.gov.lv |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
